titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Charles Owen Rice Papers, 1894-2005 AIS.1976.11
titlestmt.author: Archives Service Center Staff. Revisions occurred to the finding aid as a part of the encoding process on October 12, 1999 and May 25, 2004. The collection was reprocessed by Ashley Taylor in October 2009.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-08 11:00:57 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Charles Owen Rice was a Roman Catholic priest who was active in the Pittsburgh community as well as national labor and civil rights movements. He was involved as a journalist, as director of the Catholic Radical Alliance of Pittsburgh, as one of the founders and first chairman of the Pittsburgh Chapter of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists (ACTU), and as founder of St. Joseph's House of Hospitality (Pittsburgh). The collection includes correspondence, subject files, transcripts of radio broadcasts, manuscripts, case files, family papers, audiotapes, photographs and a film.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Msgr. Charles Owen Rice was born in New York City in 1908, the son of Irish immigrants. After his mother died when he was four, he and a brother were sent back to Ireland to be raised by an aging grandmother. By age 11, he returned to the states and was ordained into the priesthood in 1934 following studies at Duquesne University and St. Vincent Seminary, both in Pittsburgh. After ordination in 1934, he became involved with labor unions, often acting as an arbitrator. He was a leader in resisting the influence of the Communists in labor unions in the 1930s and 1940s. Partially in response to the Communist effort to control organized labor, Father Rice aided in founding the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists; he also served as its chaplain.

In 1937 Rice founded St. Joseph's House of Hospitality, giving shelter and food to homeless men in the Hill District of Pittsburgh. Labor, Communism, and St. Joseph's House were frequent topics on his weekly radio program which aired from 1937 to 1969. He and two older clergy also organized the Catholic Radical Alliance, which later became an important adjunct of the Catholic Worker movement in America. During World War II, Father Rice was appointed local rent director of the Hill District.

In 1952 Father Rice received a pastorate appointment in Natrona and later Washington, Pa., but continued his interests in labor. He walked picket lines with countless unions, protested steel plant shutdowns in the 1980s, and joined The Pittsburgh Press strikers in 1992. Although long interested in civil rights, his appointment to the predominantly African American parish of Holy Rosary in Pittsburgh's Homewood section kindled greater interest in the cause. He later became a critic of the Vietnam War. In his seven decades as a priest, Rice was pastor of numerous churches, including St. Joseph's in Natrona, Immaculate Conception in Washington, Pa., Holy Rosary in Homewood, and St. Ann's in Castle Shannon, Pa.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is comprised of 12 series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Charles Owen Rice Papers include correspondence, subject files, transcripts of Rice's radio broadcasts, manuscripts of published and unpublished writings, arbitration case files, family papers, audio tapes, photographs, and a copy of the film Humble Greatness: The Life of Philip Murray, which he narrated. The collection also includes material relating to labor, labor associations, organizations, and societies, the labor union movement, industrial unionism, strikes, politics and government, social welfare, civil rights, prison reform, the peace movement, Vietnam War protests, draft resistance, Communism, Communist leadership, Communist influence in the labor movement, anticommunism, Association of Catholic Trade Unionists and the Pittsburgh Chapter, Catholic Radical Alliance of Pittsburgh, St. Joseph's House of Hospitality (Pittsburgh), Steel Workers Organizing Committee, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, and Philip Murray.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Individual Prisoners' Case Files, Correspondence, and other prisoner information from the Prison Society of Southwest Pennsylvania (Boxes 14-16) are closed until the prisoner's death, unless written permission is provided by the prisoner.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional material was donated by Charles McCollester and Geraldine A. Mullooly in August 2006. In July 2011 Steve Rosswurm donated the files he obtained in 2009 as a result of a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request pertaining to FBI files.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Monsignor Charles Owen Rice in 1976 and 1989.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Charles Owen Rice Papers, 1935-1998, AIS.1976.11, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Charles Owen Rice Papers, 1935-1998, AIS.1976.11, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Archives Service Center Staff in the late 1970s.

Revision and rearrangement for the encoded version of the finding aid provided by Kate Colligan on October 12, 1999 and Dan Horvath on May 25, 2004. Information about the collection title and the controlled access terms was extracted from the MARC record in the University of Pittsburgh catalog Voyager ID Number: 1384010.
The additional material donated in 2006 was inventoried and weeded down by an intern. The collection was reprocessed to include the added material by Ashley Taylor in October 2009.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Permission for publication is given on behalf of the University of Pittsburgh as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission of the copyright holder, which must also be obtained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series I consists of a subject file that was created and used by Father Rice for the greater part of his career. Personal names, events and organizations are located within these files. This series contains articles, newsclippings, correspondence, pamphlets, and reports and are arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of incoming and outgoing correspondence for the years 1932 through 2004. The correspondence is divided into two subseries. The first is arranged chronologically by year, and the second is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: University of Pittsburgh, Archives of Industrial Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series III contains notes, drafts, and outlines for Father Rice's radio show and other broadcasts of sermons and lectures. This series is divided into two subseries. The first is arranged chronologically by year, and the second is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains materials relating to arbitration cases that Father Rice was involved with including cases with Teamsters, Laundy Workers, and Steelworkers. This series is divided into two subseries. The first is arranged alphabetically by subject, and the second is arranged chronologically by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series V contains materials relating to files kept by the FBI headquarters in Washington, D.C. and Pittsburgh field office on Father Rice and his activities, both in the labor and the civil rights movements. The series was split into two subseries in July 2011 with the addition of material obtained from researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains copies of files maintained by the FBI regarding Father Rice that were obtained through a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in 1977. These files were kept in Father Rice's office and were arranged chronologically. Also present is correspondence between Father Rice and the FBI regarding his FOIA request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries, created in July 2011, contains FBI files regarding Father Rice which were obtained by researcher Steve Rosswurm in 2009. These files include portions that were omitted from the records obtained by Father Rice's 1977 FOIA request. Also, these files have been maintained in their original order, reflecting the origin of the records as either the FBI headquarters or Pittsburgh field office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series VI contains materials related to Father Rice's time as Pastor of the Holy Rosary School in the Homewood section of Pittsburgh. Rice took over the school in 1966, and by 1968, he had developed a new program that he believed suited the community's children better. The program consisted of non-traditional approaches to Catholic school education where the principal was not catholic, the students did not have to wear uniforms, and there was a general sense of independence for the students. This series contains funding proposals, newsclippings, yearbooks, and letters to Father Rice from school children (1969-1974).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series VII contains manuscripts, articles, pamphlets, book reviews, sermons, and newspaper columns from the Pittsburgh Catholic. This series is divided into two subseries. The first is a collection of general manuscripts and publications, arranged alphabetically by subject. The second is material relating to Rice's Pittsburgh Catholic column, and is arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series VIII contains material that Father Rice compiled to construct his autobiography. The series includes drafts of his autobiography, as well as material he used for reference. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series IX contains biographical materials written about Father Rice, primarily Charles McCollester's Fighter With a Heart and Patrick J. McGeever's Apostle of Contradiction. It includes drafts of and correspondence regarding these publications, as well as various newspaper articles about Rice. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series X contains material on Father Rice's family, most notably correspondence with his brother Patrick Rice. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: Copy of Will of Patrick Rice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series XI contains photographs of Father Rice, primarily documenting his career as a labor and civil rights activist. Also included are photos of the Rice family, dating back to the 1880s. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically. Additional oversize material at the end of the series is also arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Series XII contains audio tapes of interviews, services, banquets, sermons, and radio broadcasts on various subjects including abortion, labor relations, Vietnam, and Ireland. This series is arranged chronologically.
